item.title: Winter Poses New Danger for Migrants
item.description: Cold weather and closing borders are complicating the arduous path from Syria and other war-torn nations into the heart of Western Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men, women and children lined up to be registered at a migrant processing center in Croatia. Most people will travel farther north to Germany or Sweden.

item.title: Swiss Anti-Immigration Party Wins Big in Elections
item.description: If the rightist parties end up winning control, the result would mark a shift from the success of moderate parties in the last elections four years ago.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Taliban Threats to Afghan Journalists Show Shift in Tactics
item.description: The Taliban, in response to what it viewed as negative coverage, threatened to kill anyone working for two of the countryâ€™s leading television channels, making personal threats to the journalists.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Lotfullah Najafizada, right, the director of ToloNews in Afghanistan, a channel that received death threats from the Taliban.

item.title: Qaeda Cell Leader Killed in Airstrike in Syria, Pentagon Says
item.description: The leader, Sanafi al-Nasr, a Saudi national, was part of a network of about two dozen Qaeda operatives called the Khorasan Group and the fifth senior member of the group to be killed in four months.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: In a Region Disturbed by Ethnic Tensions, China Keeps Tight Lid on a Massacre
item.description: More than 50 people, most of them Han Chinese, were killed in a rampage at a coal mine last month, but almost nothing is being said about it.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Despite Cuts, U.S. Army Prepares for Threats in Europe
item.description: Across-the-board spending cuts squeeze the Pentagonâ€™s budget, while a war-weary nation shows little eagerness to sustain a global, war-ready crouch.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: EMMARIE HUETTEMAN
item.media:description: United States paratroopers in Germany taking part in the largest Allied airborne training in Europe since the end of the Cold War.

item.title: In Unpredictable Canadian Elections, Plurality Is More Important Than Popularity
item.description: Each of the three big parties has led in one poll or another, but the countryâ€™s robust, dizzying political culture puts the race well beyond the reach of trustworthy handicapping.
item.dc:creator: JIM DWYER
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Mulcair of the New Democratic Party. Each of Canada's three big parties has led in one poll or another, but the countryâ€™s robust, dizzying political culture and first-past-the-post-system of simple plurality make it hard to predict an outcome.

item.title: Israeli Soldier Is Killed in Attack by Palestinian
item.description: The assailant was killed by the police during the attack in Beersheba, which wounded at least nine others and continued a string of deadly violence in Israel this month.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli police officers stood near the body of a Palestinian assailant whom they shot during an attack that wounded at least nine Sunday in Beersheba.

item.title: Editorial: French Secularism and School Lunch
item.description: A town wants to force schoolchildren to choose between eating pork and going hungry.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Mismanaging the Conflict in Jerusalem
item.description: Violence in Jerusalem Â­is rooted in rage at leaders who offer only impasse.
item.dc:creator: NATHAN THRALL

item.title: Q&A: Australian Policies on Asylum Seekers Criticized as a Denial of Free Speech
item.description: An Australian lawyer says the Border Force Act in particular has tied the hands of social workers who may want to report abuse at immigration detention centers.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Greg Barns, a lawyer and a spokesman for the Australian Lawyers Alliance.

item.title: Merkel Links Turkeyâ€™s E.U. Hopes to Stemming Flow of Refugees
item.description: The German chancellor said she would support accelerating the process of admitting Turkey to the European Union if the country cooperated in dealing with the influx of migrants into Europe.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Mieso Journal: Ethiopia, a Nation of Farmers, Strains Under Severe Drought
item.description: Millions are in need of food assistance as Ethiopiaâ€™s worst drought in a decade decimates the countryâ€™s crucial agriculture sector.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN
item.media:credit: Jacey Fortin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carcasses of dead cattle litter the landscape in northeastern Ethiopia. The country is experiencing its worst drought in a decade.

item.title: Lack of Enthusiasm Mars Latest Voting in Egypt
item.description: The contest to elect 568 lawmakers is the countryâ€™s first since 2011, but many residents expressed cynicism over its effect.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Khaled Desouki/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Voters outside a polling station in the Giza district of greater Cairo on Sunday.

item.title: Rwanda Aid Shows Reach and Limits of Clinton Fund
item.description: In addition to doing good deeds, the foundation enhances the Clinton brand, never more so than while Hillary Rodham Clinton is running for president.
item.dc:creator: KEVIN SACK and SHERI FINK
item.media:description: Former President Bill Clinton and President Paul Kagame of Rwanda greeting medical students in 2012 in Kigali, Rwanda.

item.title: Few in Venezuela Want BolÃ­vars, but No One Can Spare a Dime
item.description: The countryâ€™s currency has crashed along with its economy, despite an unchanging official exchange rate, transforming economic absurdities into daily hardships.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN and PATRICIA TORRES
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: All the freezers were empty last month in the meat department of a private grocery store in Caracas, Venezuela. Meat is among a long list of products in short supply in the country, including cooking oil, rice, coffee, soap, diapers and shampoo.

item.title: Guineaâ€™s President Is Re-elected
item.description: President Alpha CondÃ© received enough votes to avoid a runoff, the election commission said, but his opponents say they will not recognize the results.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Anger Spreads With 5 Attacks on Israelis
item.description: Palestinians had stabbed or attempted to stab five Israelis, most of them members of the security forces, according to the police and the military.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: After Strong Start in Canada Campaign, New Democrats Appear to Fade
item.description: As Mondayâ€™s vote approaches, the prospect that Tom Mulcair will lead the New Democrats, a left-of-center party, to power is diminishing.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Mulcair, leader of the New Democratic Party, during a campaign stop this month atÂ Schwartz's, a popular Montreal deli.

item.title: Britain to Put Commerce With China First in President Xi Jinpingâ€™s State Visit
item.description: The British government has been criticized by many for putting commercial interests ahead of other concerns, including human rights, cybersecurity and Chinaâ€™s growing territorial ambitions.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A worker decorating a street in Londonâ€™s Chinatown on Friday in preparation for the coming visit by President Xi Jinping of China.
